section_id: ## 9. Main Convergence Theorems and Physical Interpretation

hints.label: thm-qsd-existence
hints.title: Existence and Uniqueness of the QSD
hints.content:
2349: :label: thm-qsd-existence
2350: 
2351: The Geometric Viscous Fluid Model, composed with the cloning operator $\Psi_{\text{clone}}$, admits a unique Quasi-Stationary Distribution (QSD) $\pi_{\text{QSD}}$ on the phase space $\mathcal{X} \times \mathbb{R}^d$.
2352: 
2353: Moreover, for any initial distribution $\mu_0$, the law of the swarm at time $t$ converges exponentially fast to $\pi_{\text{QSD}}$ in total variation:
2354: 
2355: $$
2356: \|\mu_t - \pi_{\text{QSD}}\|_{\text{TV}} \le C_{\text{TV}} (1 - \kappa_{\text{total}})^t
2357: 
2358: $$
hints.section: ## 9. Main Convergence Theorems and Physical Interpretation
hints.raw_directive:
2346: ### 9.1. Theorem: Geometric Ergodicity and the QSD
2347: 
2348: :::{prf:theorem} Existence and Uniqueness of the QSD
2349: :label: thm-qsd-existence
2350: 
2351: The Geometric Viscous Fluid Model, composed with the cloning operator $\Psi_{\text{clone}}$, admits a unique Quasi-Stationary Distribution (QSD) $\pi_{\text{QSD}}$ on the phase space $\mathcal{X} \times \mathbb{R}^d$.
2352: 
2353: Moreover, for any initial distribution $\mu_0$, the law of the swarm at time $t$ converges exponentially fast to $\pi_{\text{QSD}}$ in total variation:
2354: 
2355: $$
2356: \|\mu_t - \pi_{\text{QSD}}\|_{\text{TV}} \le C_{\text{TV}} (1 - \kappa_{\text{total}})^t
2357: 
2358: $$
2359:

hints.label: proof-thm-qsd-existence
hints.title: Proof sketch
hints.content:
2364: :label: proof-thm-qsd-existence
2365: 
2366: The Foster-Lyapunov drift condition (Theorem [](#thm-fl-drift-adaptive)) implies:
2367: 1. **Petite set property:** The swarm is irreducible and aperiodic by the same arguments as in [04_convergence.md](../1_euclidean_gas/06_convergence.md) (positive diffusion, global potential, cloning operator mixing).
2368: 2. **Geometric ergodicity:** By the standard Foster-Lyapunov theorem (Meyn & Tweedie, Chapter 15), the drift condition implies the existence of a unique invariant measure $\pi_{\text{QSD}}$ and exponential convergence in the Lyapunov norm.
2369: 3. **Total variation convergence:** By the relationship between Lyapunov convergence and total variation (Theorem 16.0.1 in Meyn & Tweedie), geometric ergodicity in the Lyapunov norm implies exponential convergence in total variation.

hints.label: conj-wfr-convergence
hints.title: Convergence in the WFR Metric
hints.content:
2379: :label: conj-wfr-convergence
2380: 
2381: The composition of the kinetic evolution $\Psi_{\text{kin,adapt}}$ and the cloning selection $\Psi_{\text{clone}}$ is a contraction in the Wasserstein-Fisher-Rao (WFR) metric. Consequently, the empirical distribution converges in WFR distance:
2382: 
2383: $$
2384: \text{WFR}(\mu_t, \pi_{\text{QSD}}) \le C_{\text{WFR}} e^{-\lambda_{\text{WFR}} t}
2385: 
2386: $$
hints.section: ## 9. Main Convergence Theorems and Physical Interpretation
hints.raw_directive:
2376: The Wasserstein-Fisher-Rao (WFR) metric is a natural geometric framework for analyzing the convergence of probability distributions evolving under reaction-diffusion dynamics. We now state a formal conjecture regarding WFR convergence for the adaptive system.
2377: 
2378: :::{prf:conjecture} Convergence in the WFR Metric
2379: :label: conj-wfr-convergence
2380: 
2381: The composition of the kinetic evolution $\Psi_{\text{kin,adapt}}$ and the cloning selection $\Psi_{\text{clone}}$ is a contraction in the Wasserstein-Fisher-Rao (WFR) metric. Consequently, the empirical distribution converges in WFR distance:
2382: 
2383: $$
2384: \text{WFR}(\mu_t, \pi_{\text{QSD}}) \le C_{\text{WFR}} e^{-\lambda_{\text{WFR}} t}
2385: 
2386: $$
2387:

hints.label: rem-wfr-analogy
hints.title: Formal Analogy and Evidence
hints.content:
2417: :label: rem-wfr-analogy
2418: 
2419: Despite the lack of a complete proof, there is strong formal evidence for the conjecture:
2420: 
2421: **Structural analogy:** The adaptive system has the form of a **gradient flow in WFR space**:
2422: - The kinetic evolution is a gradient flow of the free energy in Wasserstein space
2423: - The cloning operator is a gradient flow of relative entropy in Fisher-Rao space
2424: - The WFR metric naturally interpolates between these two geometries
2425: 
2426: **Partial results:**
2427: - For the **backbone system** (without adaptive terms), W₂ contractivity follows from standard theory
2428: - For **simplified selection operators** (e.g., resampling with absolute fitness), FR contractivity is well-established
2429: - The uniform ellipticity (Theorem [](#thm-ueph)) provides the regularity needed for Wasserstein contractivity
2430: 
2431: **What would complete the proof:**
2432: 1. Extend W₂ contraction theory to uniformly elliptic, state-dependent diffusions (possible via Otto calculus)
2433: 2. Prove FR contractivity for competitive, state-dependent selection operators
2434: 3. Apply the Chizat-Peyré-Schmitzer WFR theory to verify the composition

hints.label: thm-lsi-mean-field
hints.title: Logarithmic Sobolev Inequality for the Mean-Field Generator
hints.content:
2464: :label: thm-lsi-mean-field
2465: 
2466: For the mean-field limit of the Geometric Viscous Fluid Model (as $N \to \infty$), the mean-field generator $\mathcal{L}_{\text{MF}}$ satisfies a logarithmic Sobolev inequality with respect to its unique stationary state $\rho_{\text{QSD}}$. There exists a constant $\lambda_{\text{LSI}} > 0$ such that for all probability densities $f \in H^1_w(\mathcal{X} \times \mathbb{R}^d)$:
2467: 
2468: $$
2469: \text{Ent}_{\rho_{\text{QSD}}}(f) \le \frac{1}{2\lambda_{\text{LSI}}} D(f)
2470: 
2471: $$
2472: 
2473: where:
2474: - $\text{Ent}_{\rho}(f) := \int f \log(f / \rho) \, dx \, dv$ is the relative entropy.
2475: - $D(f) := -\int (\mathcal{L}_{\text{MF}} f) \log(f / \rho_{\text{QSD}}) \, dx \, dv$ is the entropy dissipation (Fisher information).
hints.section: ## 9. Main Convergence Theorems and Physical Interpretation

hints.label: lem-dissipation-decomp
hints.title: Decomposition of Entropy Dissipation
hints.content:
2547: :label: lem-dissipation-decomp
2548: 
2549: The total entropy dissipation can be decomposed as:
2550: 
2551: $$
2552: D(f) = D_{\text{kin}}(f) + D_{\text{clone}}(f) + D_{\text{boundary}}(f)
2553: 
2554: $$
2555: 
2556: where:
2557: - $D_{\text{kin}}(f) = \int f \|\nabla_v \log(f / \rho_{\text{QSD}})\|^2_{G_{\text{reg}}} \, dx \, dv$ is the kinetic dissipation.
2558: - $D_{\text{clone}}(f) \ge 0$ is the dissipation from the selection/cloning mechanism.
2559: - $D_{\text{boundary}}(f) \ge 0$ is the dissipation from boundary flux.

hints.label: def-microlocal
hints.title: Microlocal Decomposition
hints.content:
2567: :label: def-microlocal
2568: 
2569: For any function $h = f / \rho_{\text{QSD}}$, define:
2570: - **Hydrodynamic projection:** $\Pi h(x) := \int_{\mathbb{R}^d} h(x, v) \rho_{\text{QSD}}(v | x) \, dv$
2571: - **Microscopic fluctuation:** $(I - \Pi) h := h - \Pi h$

hints.label: lem-macro-transport
hints.title: Macroscopic Transport in Absorption Form (Step B)
hints.content:
2594: :label: lem-macro-transport
2595: 
2596: **Assumption A1 (Uniform Convexity)**: The confining potential $U(x)$ satisfies:
2597: 
2598: $$
2599: \nabla^2 U(x) \succeq \kappa_{\text{conf}} I \quad \text{for all } x \in \mathcal{X}
2600: 
2601: $$
2602: 
2603: for some constant $\kappa_{\text{conf}} > 0$.
2604: 
2605: **Assumption A2 (Centered Velocities)**: The conditional velocity mean under the QSD vanishes:
2606: 
2607: $$
2608: \int v \rho_{\text{QSD}}(v | x) \, dv = 0 \quad \text{for all } x \in \mathcal{X}
2609: 
2610: $$
2611: 
2612: **Assumption A3 (Bounded Perturbation)**: The position marginal $\rho_x(x) := \int \rho_{\text{QSD}}(x, v) \, dv$ satisfies:
2613: 
2614: $$
2615: \left\| \log\left(\frac{\rho_x}{\mu_{\text{Gibbs}}}\right) \right\|_{L^\infty(\mathcal{X})} < \infty
2616: 
2617: $$
2618: 
2619: where $\mu_{\text{Gibbs}}(dx) \propto e^{-U(x)} dx$ is the Gibbs measure.
2620: 
2621: Under these assumptions, there exist constants $C_1, C_{\text{aux}} > 0$ such that for all $h \in H^1(\rho_{\text{QSD}})$ with $\int h \rho_{\text{QSD}} = 1$:
2622: 
2623: $$
2624: \|\Pi h - 1\|^2_{L^2(\rho_x)} \le C_1 \left| \langle (I - \Pi) h, v \cdot \nabla_x (\Pi h) \rangle_{L^2(\rho_{\text{QSD}})} \right| + C_{\text{aux}} \|(I - \Pi) h\|^2_{L^2(\rho_{\text{QSD}})}
2625: 
2626: $$
2627: 
2628: where:
2629: 
2630: $$
2631: C_1 = \frac{2}{\sqrt{\kappa_x c_v}}, \quad C_{\text{aux}} = \frac{1}{\kappa_x c_v}
2632: 
2633: $$
2634: 
2635: with:
2636: - $\kappa_x \ge \kappa_{\text{conf}} e^{-2 C_{\text{pert}}}$ (position Poincaré constant)
2637: - $c_v = \frac{\sigma^2}{2\gamma}$ (velocity covariance lower bound)

hints.label: proof-lem-macro-transport
hints.content:
2643: :label: proof-lem-macro-transport
2644: 
2645: This proof follows the classical hypocoercivity approach of Villani (2009) adapted to the QSD setting. The key steps are:
2646: 
2647: **Preliminary Lemmas**:
2648: 
2649: *Lemma A (Position Poincaré)*: Under Assumptions A1 (uniform convexity) and A3 (bounded perturbation), the position marginal $\rho_x$ satisfies a Poincaré inequality:
2650: 
2651: $$
2652: \|a\|^2_{L^2(\rho_x)} \le \frac{1}{\kappa_x} \|\nabla_x a\|^2_{L^2(\rho_x)}
2653: 
2654: $$
2655: 
2656: for all mean-zero $a \in H^1(\rho_x)$, where $\kappa_x \ge \kappa_{\text{conf}} e^{-2 C_{\text{pert}}}$ by the Holley-Stroock perturbation theorem.
2657: 
2658: *Lemma B (Velocity Covariance)*: Under Assumption A2 (centered velocities), the conditional velocity covariance satisfies:
2659: 
2660: $$
2661: \Sigma_v(x) := \int v v^\top \rho_{\text{QSD}}(v | x) \, dv \succeq c_v I
2662: 
2663: $$
2664: 
2665: where $c_v = \frac{\sigma^2}{2\gamma}$ (derived via Lyapunov equation for the Ornstein-Uhlenbeck velocity process).
2666: 
2667: *Lemma C (Orthogonality)*: Under Assumption A2, for any function $a(x)$ depending only on position:
2668: 
2669: $$
2670: \Pi[v \cdot \nabla_x a] = 0
2671: 
2672: $$
2673: 
2674: **Main Proof**:
2675: 
2676: **Step 1**: Apply position Poincaré to the centered macroscopic part $a(x) := \Pi h(x) - 1$. By normalization $\int h \rho_{\text{QSD}} = 1$, we have $\int a \rho_x = 0$, so:
2677: 
2678: $$
2679: \|\Pi h - 1\|^2_{L^2(\rho_x)} \le \frac{1}{\kappa_x} \|\nabla_x (\Pi h)\|^2_{L^2(\rho_x)}
2680: 
2681: $$
2682: 
2683: **Step 2**: Express position gradient via transport energy. Using the velocity covariance lower bound:
2684: 
2685: $$
2686: \|\nabla_x (\Pi h)\|^2_{L^2(\rho_x)} \le \frac{1}{c_v} \|v \cdot \nabla_x (\Pi h)\|^2_{L^2(\rho_{\text{QSD}})}
2687: 
2688: $$
2689: 
2690: **Step 3**: Combine Steps 1-2 to obtain macroscopic coercivity:
2691: 
2692: $$
2693: \|\Pi h - 1\|^2_{L^2(\rho_x)} \le \frac{1}{\kappa_x c_v} \|v \cdot \nabla_x (\Pi h)\|^2_{L^2(\rho_{\text{QSD}})}
2694: 
2695: $$
2696: 
2697: **Step 4**: Apply absorption technique. By Lemma C, $v \cdot \nabla_x (\Pi h)$ is purely microscopic ($\Pi[v \cdot \nabla_x (\Pi h)] = 0$), so by Cauchy-Schwarz:
2698: 
2699: $$
2700: \|v \cdot \nabla_x (\Pi h)\|_{L^2} \ge \frac{|\langle (I - \Pi) h, v \cdot \nabla_x (\Pi h) \rangle_{L^2}|}{\|(I - \Pi) h\|_{L^2}}
2701: 
2702: $$
2703: 
2704: Using Young's inequality $ab \le \frac{a^2}{2\epsilon} + \frac{\epsilon b^2}{2}$ with optimal choice $\epsilon = 1$ yields the absorption form:
2705: 
2706: $$
2707: \|\Pi h - 1\|^2_{L^2(\rho_x)} \le \frac{2}{\sqrt{\kappa_x c_v}} |\langle (I - \Pi) h, v \cdot \nabla_x (\Pi h) \rangle_{L^2}| + \frac{1}{\kappa_x c_v} \|(I - \Pi) h\|^2_{L^2}
2708: 
2709: $$
2710: 
2711: with $C_1 = \frac{2}{\sqrt{\kappa_x c_v}}$ and $C_{\text{aux}} = \frac{1}{\kappa_x c_v}$.
2712:

2708: 
2709: $$

2711: with $C_1 = \frac{2}{\sqrt{\kappa_x c_v}}$ and $C_{\text{aux}} = \frac{1}{\kappa_x c_v}$.
